author: Cuppa Joe

text: so much nostalgia...
author: olinar90

text:
@SupraDarky I have to agree with you, in that DK64 was a big letdown. It seems like every franchise was getting a 3D makeover at the time, regardless if the idea behind the game was a good one. This was the first game I tested at Nintendo, and I felt it was just an unsatisfying collection simulator, with a couple cool boss battles and multiplayer for variety. I enjoyed the next game I tested much more: Rare's Jet Force Gemini.
As memorable as it is, I think the rap is the worst song in the game.
author: sevinPackage

text: @SupraDarky While the game definitely had its flaws, and it might not have seemed good as a sequal to the DKC games, I still think it managed a lot of good on its own - it felt like it gave the biggest sense of exploration of the 64-era 3D platformers, and some of the areas carried some incredible ambience.  Either way, yeah - invariably you walked out of this game remember something, and chances are it was this intro.

author: Icyytouch

text: I actually enjoyed this one very much. Probably because I was late to the 3D era, & this actually was my first 3D game ever. However, I think much of it's problem was that, well, how else is it that Rareware had so many hits on the N64 other than the fact that a # of them were just repeats? Tell me Goldeneye and Perfect Dark weren't copies of each other, and this is basically Banjo-Kazooie. Hmm, I guess that makes it kind of ironic Banjo-Tooie and Conkler are my favs since they came last then...
